question:
Study the farm tools illustrated by diagrams I -VI below and use them to answer Questions 1(a) - (c).

(a) Name the tools illustrated by diagram I -VI

(b) State one use of each of the tools illustrated by diagrams I -VI.

(c) State one method of maintenance for each of the tools illustrated by diagrams I -VI.
answer:
(a) Farm tools;

  • I = Knapsacks sprayer
  • Il = Watering can
  • Ill = Sieve
  • IV = Sickle (short handle)
  • V = Spanner
  • VI = Feeder/ Waterer

(b) Uses;

  • I - Spraying chemicals such as pesticides, insecticides, herbicides and liquid fertilizers.
  • Il - application of water to crops (during the season), application of liquid fertilizers.
  • IlI - used for separation of soil particles., to sieve compost of F.Y.M. to make nursery soil., to analyse the texture of the soil., for seed separation in seed processing
  • IV - used for harvesting fruits/cereal crops., used for cutting grass pasture for animals
  • V -used for loosening and tightening of nuts on farm machinery.
  • VI - used for feeding chicks/fowls in poultry farm., used also as drinker to provide water for chicks/fowls.

(c) Methods of maintenance;

  • I -should be properly rinsed with water after use to get rid of left-over chemicals. Open up clogged nozzle or clean the nozzle and keep it in a cool, dry place.
  • Il - should be drained after use, stored upside down; rinse /wash with water if used for liquid fertilizers; keep in a cool dry place.
  • Ill - store in a cool, dry place and clean after use
  • IV -sharpen regularly the blunt edges; apply grease to avoid rusting and clean after use and store in an area free regularly. from rain and termites. 
  • V - store in a cool dry place and clean after use.
  • VI - store in a cool, dry place and clean

question:
The diagram below illustrates the process of compost making. Use it to answer questions (a) to (d)

(a) Name the end-product obtained.

(b) State five advantages of the end-product mentioned in (a)

(c) A vertical section was made through a piece of virgin land.
(i) By means of a labeled diagram, illustrate what would be observed from the vertical section.
(ii) What is the name given to the diagram made in (c)(i)?

(d) During a trip to the school farm, it was observed that maize plants were stunted and the leaves were yellowish in colour.
(i) What mineral deficiency is responsible for these changes? 
(ii) How can the deficiency symptoms be corrected?
answer:
.(a) The end product of compost making is organic manure or compost

(b) Advantages of Organic manure:

  • It promotes the activities of living creatures or microorganisms in the soil.
  • It adds more humus to the soil, thus increasing the nutrients for plants growth. 
  • It improves soil structure by binding loose particles together.
  • absorbs heat readily during the day and loses it slowly during the night due to its dark colour.  
  • It controls soil temperature.
  • It helps to conserve soil water.
  • It balances the acid/base condition of the soil.
  • it prevents erosion by improving the structure and reducing run-off.
  • It aids aeration of the soil.

(c)(i) Vertical section through a virgin land

(ii) The diagram is a soil profile

(d)(i) The crops are deficient in nitrogen,
(ii) Deficiency symptoms are corrected by the application of nitrogenous fertilizers, e.g. NPK, Urea, (NH\(_{4}\)), SO\(_{4}\), Ammonium nitrate.

question:
A farmer applied one-third of the required amount of N.P.K fertilizer to 2 hectares of maize at the rate of 50 kg N.P.K, fertilizer per hectare, two weeks after planting.

Use the information above to answer questions (a) to (d) below:

(a) If the spacing of maize crops was 60 cm x 91 cm, calculate the plant population on the farm:

(b) Calculate the total quantity of fertilizer used on the farm.

(c) Calculate the amount of fertilizer applied during the first two weeks of planting the maize crops.

(d) Calculate the quantity of fertilizer applied per stand at two weeks.
answer:
(a) Iha = 10\(^{4}\)m\(^{2}\) or 10\(^{8}\)cm\(^{2}\)
plant popu./ha = \(\frac{10^{8} cm^{2}}{60 \times 91cm^{2}}\) = 18315 plants

\(\frac{10^{8} cm^{2} \times 2}{60 \times 91cm^{2}}\)

= 18,315 x 2 = 36,630 plants

(b) Total amount of fertilizer required for the farm;
Rate = 50kg / hectare
For 2 hectares = 50 x 2 = 100kg

(c) Amount of fertilizer applied at the first two weeks of planting;
Rate = 50kg / hectare
Total = 100kg for 2hectares
Required for the first two weeks = \(\frac{1}{3}\) x 100kg = 33.3kg of NPK fertilizer

(d) Quality of fertilizer per stand at two weeks
= \(\frac {\text {Quantity of fertilizer}} {\text {No of Stands}}\) = \(\frac {33.2 \times 100 {\text {grams}}} {36,630}\) = 0.9gm or 1.00gm

question:
The diagram below represents an incubator. Study it carefully and use it to answer questions (a) - (e).

(a) List four components of the incubator.

(b) Explain two problems that can affect the proper functioning of any two of the components listed in (a).

(c) State three steps that should be taken to ensure that the eggs hatch at about the same time.

(d)(i) State the type of housing system adopted for breeding fowls to ensure a high rate of egg fertility.
(ii) Give reason for your answer.

(e) State two activities normally carried out by the farmer in the hatchery after hatching
answer:
(a) Components of the incubator are:

  • heat source
  • lantern,
  • heater,
  • Electric heater.
  • Control unit
  • damper and thermostat.
  • heat distribution unit.
  • relative humidity mediation unit
  • basin of water
  • cotton wool
  • humidifier.
  • felt tray (to hold eggs and reduces cracking),
  • Egg rack,
  • Egg tray.
  • thermometer to detect degree of hotness and coldness
  • air circulation unit vents for ventilation and fan.
  • Egg turming device,
  • Insulator.

(b) Problem of functioning components: Electrical incubator:

  • Power failure
  • Iregular power supply.

For Kerosene Heat:

  • High / low voltage/ current

For Thermostat:

  • High / low voltage/ current.

For Fan:

  • Irregular power supply; Overheating caused by over-usage. Loose nuts of the parts; improper lubrication of the movable parts.

For Thermometer:

  • Cracking or breakage of the bulb/thermometer and loss of sensitivity.

For Ventilation:

  • Blockage of vents, Water Basin - Leakage, Dryíng-up of water content.

Insulator:

  • Puncturing of the insulator unit turning devices for egg tray, Lubrication of the movable joints/ parts, Loose nuts.

(C) Efforts to ensure uniformity of hatching:

  • setting eggs uniformly in the tray,
  • timely and regular turning of eggs,
  • ensure suitable environmental conditions
  • temperature, ventilation, and relative humidity.
  • proper handling of the eggs,
  • setting eggs at the same time,
  • holding period of egg before setting ( not more than 14 days).

(d) The housing type that ensures a high rate of egg fertility is Deep litter.

Reasons: mating of birds is regular and without hindrance.

(e) Activities to be carried out after hatching are-

  • sexing of chicks;
  • dryíng of chicks and intra -ocular.
  • NDV vaccination,
  • sorting out abnormal chicks and packing.
